Award.AwardTitle: Pre-Alliance Planning: The Bridges Across Texas Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The number of underrepresented students is increasing and more of these students are pursuing college degrees, but their completion rate for baccalaureate science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) degrees still lags the general population. The Bridges Across Texas LSAMP (BAT LSAMP) Pre-Alliance will bring together personnel from six institutions of higher learning to develop a plan to improve recruitment, retention, and graduation of underrepresented students, with a focus on students transferring from community colleges into STEM majors at four-year universities. The overarching goal of the project is to strengthen the pipeline from community colleges to four-year institutions, and address the growing STEM workforce needs of the State of Texas.

This Pre-Alliance will focus on evaluating: (i) underrepresented students' attitudes, barriers, and needs; (ii) existing capacity and gaps in STEM curriculum at partner institutions; (iii) underrepresented students recruitment and retention strategies; (iv) transfer barriers at the four-year institution partners; and (v) infrastructure needs at each partner institution. Over 18 months, the project will administer student and administrator questionnaires, conduct focus-group meetings, and hold meetings to identify the barriers faced by and needs of underrepresented STEM students. The data gathered will inform policy and produce practices that meet students' needs, with an ultimate goal of increasing enrollment and completion of STEM degrees by underrepresented students. The intellectual merit of the project is that it will generate practical knowledge regarding how relationships between two-year and four-year institutions develop and strengthen, and will offer insights into how institutions of higher education can collectively support students' diverse pathways through the higher education landscape.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of Bridges Across Texas LSAMP (BAT LSAMP) was to collect student, faculty, and administrator data to identify what is needed to enable successful recruitment, retention, and graduation of underrepresented minority (African-American and Hispanic) students (URMs) who start at 4-year institutions or community colleges and then transfer into (STEM) majors at four-year institutions. BAT LSAMP was a new collaboration of six institutions of higher education in Texas that serve a geographically large and demographically diverse region that otherwise lacks LSAMP support. This collective endeavor was more successful than each institution working independently to identify and subsequently address barriers to URM success in STEM majors. During the 18-month effort, information was collected to identify the needs and barriers of URM STEM majors at each institution. The information was collected via focus groups and questionnaires.

 

Data were collected from 500 students and 214 faculty/staff/administrators across the six partners about barriers to retention and successful transfer to a four-year program. Emergent themes were identified from both populations. The majority of student respondents were URM STEM majors, and they described their STEM affiliation with pride. Students described how early exposure to STEM content in middle or high school provided motivation and inspiration for them to study STEM. However, they reported feeling pressure to succeed from family, faculty, or employers. As such, they made intentional decisions about their degree paths and career plans, and explained the importance of advocating for themselves, but they reported significant barriers to them remaining in school and in STEM:

  1. Knowledge of resources available to students was critical to their perceptions of their own success.
  2. Mentoring was perceived by students as a key component of their future success. Many students reported specifically about how a faculty member directly or indirectly made them want to stay in their degree program.
  3. Advising was crucial, especially for the transition from two-year to four-year institutions.
  4. Scholarships, paid internships, or other sources of financial aid were a key limiting factor to many.

 

To address these needs, students indicated that they needed quality advising, information about careers and internships, financial support and financial aid opportunities, faculty mentoring, and a sense of belonging. Students reported that academic advising services and personal counseling services were of great benefit.

 

The faculty/staff/administrators indicated that most were aware that URMs in STEM face challenges; overcoming a poor K-12 educational background leads to a lack of preparation or readiness for STEM in college. However, relatively few knew how to provide more support and encouragement to help students address those challenges, or had implemented changes in their classrooms. This was significant, given that students themselves indicated that faculty are critical for student retention. Many faculty/staff/administrators indicated they were aware of the importance of family or a social support system in a student’s success and the need for role models (particularly with underrepresentation of minorities in STEM fields and racial discrimination or stereotypes faced by URMs in STEM).

 

Based on these data, we identified four categories of barriers faced by URMs in STEM:

  • Physical resources (e.g. finances, books, computer or internet access, study space);
  • Mentoring and tutoring;
  • Information about courses, majors, career options, internships, jobs, etc.;
  • Social support/community identity (sense of belonging).

 

Upon project completion, the members of the BAT LSAMP were asked what they thought was the most important finding to come out of the Pre-Alliance. Several respondents indicated that they were surprised at the lack of advising targeted towards URMs in STEM, especially since this was identified by students themselves as an important need. Some respondents indicated that despite the fact that institutions have various support services in place to facilitate student success, many underrepresented students still felt lost in a college environment. These students may feel that they are not being communicated with, or at least that the things they see as important are not being communicated with them. The need for a physical space to students to interact academically and socially, to form connections that create a strong academic and social structure and sense of community, was also noted. Finally, it was noted that URM students face the same kinds of barriers regardless of institution type; these commonalities suggest that bridges over these barriers are possible.    

 

Based on these responses, the BAT LSAMP team developed a series of recommendations in enhancing graduation rates by URMs in four-year STEM degree programs. To operationalize these recommendations, we developed a full Alliance proposal (submitted November 2019, not funded) that would have established a STEM Center at each campus, with campuses linked virtually to share resources, provide mentoring and tutoring opportunities, create a sense of community identity for URMs, and provide information. This model was based on successful development of a STEM Center at one of the community college partners.
